mn24:3.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
mn24:3.3: Then several mendicant who had spent the rainy season in their native land went to the Buddha,
mn24:3.4: bowed, and sat down to one side.
mn24:4.1: “In your native land, mendicants, who of the native mendicants is esteemed in this way?
mn24:4.2: Personally having few wishes, they speak to the mendicants on having few wishes. Personally having contentment, seclusion, aloofness, energy, ethics, samādhi, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom, they speak to the mendicants on all these things. They’re an adviser and instructor, one who educates, encourages, fires up, and inspires their spiritual companions.”
mn24:4.3: “Puṇṇa Mantāṇiputta, sir, is esteemed in this way in our native land.”
mn24:5.1: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was meditating not far from the Buddha.
mn24:5.3: “Puṇṇa Mantāṇiputta is fortunate, so very fortunate, in that his sensible spiritual companions praise him point by point in the presence of the Teacher, and that the teacher seconds that appreciation.
mn24:5.4: Hopefully, some time or other I’ll get to meet Venerable Puṇṇa, and we can have a discussion.”
mn24:6.1: Then the Buddha—when he had stayed in Rājagaha as long as he wished—set out for Sāvatthī.
mn24:6.2: Travelling stage by stage, he arrived at Sāvatthī,
mn24:6.3: where he stayed in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn24:6.5: that the Buddha had arrived at Sāvatthī.
mn24:7.1: Then he set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robes, set out for Sāvatthī.
mn24:7.2: Eventually he came to Sāvatthī and Jeta’s Grove. He went up to the Buddha,
mn24:7.3: bowed, and sat down to one side.
mn24:7.4: The Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired him with a Dharma talk.
mn24:7.5: Then, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, Puṇṇa got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he went up to the Blind Man’s Wood for the day’s meditation.
mn24:8.1: Then a certain mendicant went up to Venerable Sāriputta,
mn24:8.3: “Reverend Sāriputta, the mendicant named Puṇṇa, of whom you have often spoken so highly, after being inspired by a talk of the Buddha’s, left for the Blind Man’s Wood for the day’s meditation.”
mn24:9.1: Sāriputta quickly grabbed his sitting cloth and followed behind Puṇṇa, keeping sight of his head.
mn24:9.2: Puṇṇa plunged deep into the Dark Forest and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.
mn24:10.1: Then in the late afternoon, Sāriputta came out of solitude, went to Puṇṇa,
mn24:10.3: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
mn24:11.1: “Reverend, is our spiritual life lived under the Buddha?”
mn24:13.1: “Is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for the sake of purification of ethics?”
mn24:15.1: “Then is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for the sake of purification of mind?”
mn24:17.1: “Is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for the sake of purification of view?”
mn24:19.1: “Then is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for the sake of going beyond doubt?”
mn24:21.1: “Is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for the sake of purification of knowledge and vision of what is the path and what is not the path?”
mn24:23.1: “Then is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for the sake of purification of knowledge and vision of the practice?”
mn24:25.1: “Is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for the sake of purification of knowledge and vision?”
mn24:27.1: “When asked each of these questions, you answered, ‘Certainly not.’
mn24:27.12: Then what exactly is the purpose of living the spiritual life under the Buddha?”
mn24:27.13: “The purpose of living the spiritual life under the Buddha is extinguishment without grasping.”
mn24:28.1: “Reverend, is purification of ethics extinguishment without grasping?”
mn24:40.1: “Is purification of knowledge and vision extinguishment without grasping?”
mn24:42.1: “Then is extinguishment without grasping something apart from these things?”
mn24:44.1: “When asked each of these questions, you answered, ‘Certainly not.’
mn24:44.10: How then should we see the meaning of this statement?”
mn24:45.1: “If the Buddha had declared purification of ethics to be extinguishment without grasping, he would have declared that which has grasping to be extinguishment without grasping. …
mn24:45.7: If the Buddha had declared purification of knowledge and vision to be extinguishment without grasping, he would have declared that which has grasping to be extinguishment without grasping.
mn24:45.8: But if extinguishment without grasping was something apart from these things, an ordinary person would become extinguished.
mn24:45.9: For an ordinary person lacks these things.
mn24:45.10: Well then, reverend, I shall give you a simile.
mn24:45.11: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.
mn24:46.1: Suppose that, while staying in Sāvatthī, King Pasenadi of Kosala had some urgent business come up in Sāketa.
mn24:46.2: Now, between Sāvatthī and Sāketa seven prepared chariots were stationed ready for him.
mn24:46.3: Then Pasenadi having departed Sāvatthī, mounted the first prepared chariot by the gate of the royal compound. The first prepared chariot would bring him to the second, where he’d dismount and mount the second chariot.
mn24:46.4: The second prepared chariot would bring him to the third …
mn24:46.5: The third prepared chariot would bring him to the fourth …
mn24:46.6: The fourth prepared chariot would bring him to the fifth …
mn24:46.7: The fifth prepared chariot would bring him to the fourth …
mn24:46.8: The sixth prepared chariot would bring him to the seventh, where he’d dismount and mount the seventh chariot.
mn24:46.9: The seventh prepared chariot would bring him to the gate of the royal compound of Sāketa.
mn24:46.10: And when he was at the gate, friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would ask him:
mn24:46.11: ‘Great King, did you come to Sāketa from Sāvatthī by this prepared chariot?’
mn24:46.12: If asked this, how should King Pasenadi rightly reply?”
mn24:47.2: ‘Well, while staying in Sāvatthī, I had some urgent business come up in Sāketa.
mn24:47.3: Now, between Sāvatthī and Sāketa seven prepared chariots were stationed ready for me.
mn24:47.4: Then, having departed Sāvatthī, I mounted the first prepared chariot by the gate of the royal compound.
mn24:47.5: The first prepared chariot brought me to the second, where I dismounted and mounted the second chariot. …
mn24:47.10: The sixth prepared chariot brought me to the seventh, where I dismounted and mounted the seventh chariot.
mn24:47.11: The seventh prepared chariot brought me to the gate of the royal compound of Sāketa.’
mn24:47.12: That’s how King Pasenadi should rightly reply.”
mn24:48.1: “In the same way, reverend, purification of ethics is only for the sake of purification of mind. … Purification of knowledge and vision is only for the sake of extinguishment without grasping.
mn24:48.2: The spiritual life is lived under the Buddha for the sake of extinguishment without grasping.”
mn24:49.1: When he said this, Sāriputta said to Puṇṇa:
mn24:49.2: “What is the venerable’s name? And how are you known among your spiritual companions?”
mn24:49.4: And I am known as Mantāṇiputta among my spiritual companions.”
mn24:49.6: Venerable Puṇṇa Mantāṇiputta has answered each deep question point by point, as a learned disciple who rightly understands the teacher’s instructions.
mn24:49.7: It is fortunate for his spiritual companions, so very fortunate, that they get to see Venerable Puṇṇa Mantāṇiputta and pay homage to him.
mn24:49.8: Even if they only got to see him and pay respects to him by carrying him around on their heads on a roll of cloth, it would still be very fortunate for them! And it’s fortunate for me, so very fortunate, that I get to see the Venerable and pay homage to him.”
mn24:50.1: When he said this, Puṇṇa said to Sāriputta:
mn24:50.2: “What is the venerable’s name? And how are you known among your spiritual companions?”
mn24:50.4: And I am known as Sāriputta among my spiritual companions.”
mn24:50.5: “Goodness! I had no idea I was consulting with the Venerable Sāriputta, the disciple who is fit to be compared with the Teacher himself!
mn24:50.7: If I’d known, I wouldn’t have said so much.
mn24:50.9: Venerable Sāriputta has asked each deep question point by point, as a learned disciple who rightly understands the teacher’s instructions.
mn24:50.10: It is fortunate for his spiritual companions, so very fortunate, that they get to see Venerable Sāriputta and pay homage to him.
mn24:50.11: Even if they only got to see him and pay respects to him by carrying him around on their heads on a roll of cloth, it would still be very fortunate for them! And it’s fortunate for me, so very fortunate, that I get to see the Venerable and pay homage to him.”
mn24:51.1: And so these two spiritual giants agreed with each others’ well spoken words.
